text:
With flumine the target is making a simple framework which is going to come at a cost of performance. 
However eventually we can add the ability to use lightweight mode and handle the raw json, this will rapidly speed up backtesting, not worth it for the 99% when live trading unless speed is a priority or you are processing lots of markets. 

Very keen on benchmarking, with my own framework it’s about a minute for each racing market or sub 10s when using lightweight mode. I use a variation of threads, processes and AWS lambda for overnight backtesting.

here is my numbers using lightweight and decoded updates

text: has anyone ever come up with a method to test the efficiency of odds before (e.g. 2-3 days) an event? everything I come accross only talks about efficiency of closing odds (final odds before a race starts)

text: <@U92CASP1B> I notice that you are using a data from Dec 2019 to do your benchmarking. Are you able to share that (without getting in trouble), so that I can test against the same file? If not, could we try to use a common file from the recent free historical data that Betfair has provided? For example, I am now running it against 29639024, an AU horse racing data from 1st April 2020. The pro data is free for April.

text: I'm not that sure that they will be less efficient. 3 days before a race, there is less information that right before the race. To correctly measure efficiency, I think one should account for this "lack of information" that does not occur right before the race

text:
It’s a point to make, seems very tangential to the current conversation though. 

The proof is in the pudding so if using Windows makes you money then great. 

However it’s hard to take seriously anyone that tries to argue Windows is anything other than a distant third choice platform to develop or run algorithmic trading strategies on.
